Description: Terracotta scaraboid-mould in Nile clay; mould of depressed conical shape, with flat area round impression, roughly heptagonal in shape; impression of a Black African head with characteristic facial features and braided hair; hairline indicated by inverted w-shape with lattice work pattern at side, below main lines of curls indicated by tear-shaped indentations; on forehead a pair of V-shaped 'horns' run up from top of nose to hair line; large bulbous eyes set wide apart, short nose with wide nostrils, and wide lips; ears indicated as small circles with hole in middle; no visible remains of paste/glaze inside impression; in pale orange brown micaceous Nile silt fabric.
Curator's comments: Glazed composition scarabs and scaraboids produced at Naukratis were usually cast and not carved or incised; this technique, highly characteristic of Naukratite productions, allowed a mass-production of these small objects which were mainly intended for export in the whole Mediterranean area and even as far as Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 177-180, fig. 35). Numerous terracotta moulds for scarabs, scaraboids and amulets were discovered at the site (on the various productions from the Scarab Factory see Webb, forthcoming). Scaraboids in the shape of a Black African head are a standard production at Naukratis. Petrie listed a number of variants for Black African head scaraboid-moulds (Petrie 1886, 37, pl. XXXVIII, 8-11), though not exactly this type. Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implication for dating, in R. Thomas (ed.), The Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OI.003) (phase 2)
Condition: Good, except for chip on outer edge of mould.
